Description: Egyptian mould-made lamp. Flat pear-shaped base with elongated body and raised moulded or stamped decoration of rosettes within circles on rim. Decoration of curved lines on concave discus. The broad shallow channel from edge of discus to nozzle is slightly blackened through use. Pale buff-brown fabric with no mica visible. Broken and mended.
Curator's comments: Object owned and held by University of Pennsylvania Museum of Archaeology and Anthropology, Philadelphia. This record is included in the British Museum database as part of the Museum’s Naukratis Project, a research collaboration that aims to virtually re-unite finds from the ancient port city of Naukratis, now distributed over 80 museums worldwide.

Oval carinated, or 'grooved type', lamps, copying imports from the Late Roman and Islamic Levant during the 6th and 7th century AD, were produced in the North-West Delta, probably at Alexandria (Bailey 1988, 232, , Q2203-7), where parallels in the British Museum were found and dated to the 7th century AD (Bailey 1988, Q2266 and Q2267). End 6th to beginning of the 7th century BC parallels from Kom el-Dikka, Alexandria (Mlynarczyk 1998, 350, Fig 23). Parallel from Roman Ehnasya of a 'grooved type' lamp (Petrie 1905, pl. 62; Corinth 4.2, 119 for dating) is given as a reference on the Philadelphia register card. Mlynarczyk, J. 1998. Terracotta mould-made lamps in Alexandria (Hellenistic to Late Roman period), in Empereur, J-Y. (ed.), Commerce et Artisant dans l’Alexandrie Hellénistique et Romaine, Paris, 327-52. Petrie, W.M.Fl. 1905. Roman Ehnasya (Herakleopolis Magna), 1904. London.
Bibliographic references: Villing et al 2013-2015 / Naukratis: Greeks in Egypt (KF.02) (Phase 1)
